title: Levinas: Ethics as First Philosophy
description: Comprehensive identification review covering Emmanuel Levinas' philosophy, the Face, responsibility, and the Other.

flashcards.front: A 20th-century French philosopher of Jewish descent whose life and work were deeply shaped by the Holocaust.
The country where Emmanuel Levinas was originally from.
The traumatic event that forced Levinas to rethink good, evil, free will, and God's role in suffering.
flashcards.back: The Holocaust (his family in Lithuania was murdered during WWII)

flashcards.front: An attempt to justify God's goodness despite the existence of evil, implying there is a divine reason for suffering.
Levinas' response to theodicy after the Holocaust.
flashcards.back: Theodicy is dead; nothing can justify the suffering of others

flashcards.front: According to Levinas, what God does NOT do regarding suffering.
flashcards.back: God does not 'will' suffering for a higher purpose

flashcards.front: The traditional starting points of philosophy before Levinas.
flashcards.back: Metaphysics (what is real?) or Theology (who is God?)

flashcards.front: What Levinas argued should be the 'First Philosophy.'
According to Levinas, the most fundamental human experience.
The level at which we feel responsibility when we face someone else, before thinking or analyzing.
What reacts to the Other before our brains even catch up, according to Levinas.
What Levinas says suffering engages when we encounter it.
What we should NOT do when seeing someone in pain, according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: Try to explain it away (like saying 'It's God's will')

flashcards.front: What we should do when seeing someone in pain, according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: Engage our compassion and be present

flashcards.front: How God acts in the world according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: Through US; by helping others, we bring God into the world

flashcards.front: The Western philosophical tendency to group everyone under one label, treating people as a collective mass rather than individuals.
The assumption that we can surpass our differences because we all 'think in the same manner.'
The risk created when Western philosophy groups everyone as 'Beings.'
flashcards.back: Totality (treating people as a collective mass)

flashcards.front: The concept drawn from Hebrew teachings that insists on uniqueness giving us our true identity.
What gives us our true identity according to Levinas' concept of Singularity.
The nature of the 'Good' in Levinas' philosophy.
flashcards.back: Infinite (cannot be fully captured or defined by one person)

flashcards.front: What philosophy is ultimately searching for according to Levinas.
How we can encounter traces of the Infinite Good.
flashcards.back: By embracing uniqueness (respecting each person's singularity)

flashcards.front: What happens when we force everyone to be the 'same.'
What we open the door to when we respect each person's singularity.
What the Good is not, according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: A static object (it is an encounter)

flashcards.front: Where the Good is found according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: In the unique face of the Other

flashcards.front: Levinas' most famous concept explaining how the mere presence of another person creates ethical obligation.
The only way we encounter the infinite Good, since we cannot capture it directly.
What the Face witnesses or testifies to.
How Levinas describes the Other (the stranger) in relation to oneself.
Why the Other is considered superior according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: They carry a trace of the Divine

flashcards.front: What you cannot do to the Other according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: Possess or change them to be like you

flashcards.front: The nature of the Other's difference.
When the Face displays ethics most clearly.
flashcards.back: When it is weak or powerless (like a stranger, widow, or orphan)

flashcards.front: The paradox of the Face in Levinas' ethics.
flashcards.back: The Face is exposed and vulnerable (you could hurt it), yet it issues a divine command: 'Thou Shalt Not Kill'

flashcards.front: The divine command issued by the vulnerable Face.
How God speaks to us according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: Through humanity (through the face of others)

flashcards.front: What you are hearing when you look at the vulnerable face of a stranger.
What draws you in and makes you responsible without your choice.
Where the search for God ends according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: At the Face of your neighbor (not in heaven)

flashcards.front: What comes before freedom and thinking in Levinas' ethics.
The nature of responsibility according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: Incumbent on me (whether I accept it or not)

flashcards.front: What the face forbids us to do according to Levinas.
What the nakedness or vulnerability of the face orders us to do.
In philosophy, what 'the Other' simply refers to.
flashcards.back: Another human being who is not you

flashcards.front: What determines whether we treat the Other ethically or just use them.
flashcards.back: How we think about this other person

flashcards.front: The two major philosophers (Phenomenologists) who focused heavily on the Self before Levinas.
How pre-Levinas philosophers (like Hegel and Husserl) viewed the Self.
flashcards.back: The Self (Subject) is king; it's all about me

flashcards.front: How pre-Levinas philosophers viewed the Other.
flashcards.back: As an object to be studied and understood

flashcards.front: The 'Mirror Effect' in pre-Levinas philosophy.
flashcards.back: Thinking 'that person is just like me; they are an alter-ego'

flashcards.front: Levinas' term for forcing people to fit into your understanding of the world.
What Levinas called viewing others only as reflections of yourself.
Levinas' first radical shift regarding the Other.
flashcards.back: The Other is NOT an object

flashcards.front: What the Other will always be to you, according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: A mystery (you cannot fully know or possess them)

flashcards.front: What you should respect instead of trying to analyze the Other.
Levinas' approach to the Other instead of understanding them.
Your primary job regarding the Other according to Levinas.
flashcards.back: To welcome them, not to understand them

flashcards.front: Levinas' most famous claim about philosophy.
Where traditional philosophy starts.
flashcards.back: With knowledge (trying to figure out what things are)

flashcards.front: Where Levinas' philosophy starts.
flashcards.back: With responsibility (responding to the person in front of you)

flashcards.front: What you are even before you think, speak, or analyze.
flashcards.back: Responsible for the person facing you

flashcards.front: How traditional philosophy treats the Other.
flashcards.back: As an object or a version of the Self

flashcards.front: How Levinas treats the Other.
flashcards.back: As a superior Stranger who demands our respect

flashcards.front: The philosophy of knowing that focuses on the Self.
The philosophy of welcoming that focuses on the Other.
The shift Levinas made from traditional philosophy.
flashcards.back: From a philosophy of knowing (Egology) to a philosophy of welcoming (Ethics)

flashcards.front: The property of being different or 'other' that should be respected.
The three characteristics the Other holds according to Levinas.
Ellen DeGeneres' quote that echoes Levinas' philosophy.
flashcards.back: Sometimes you can't see yourself clearly until you see yourself through the eyes of another
